Problem:
Consider a dynamic model where the temperature of a system \\( T \\) is governed by the heat equation \\( \\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\nabla^2 T \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is the thermal diffusivity. We investigate the effect of an initial condition modification characterized by \\( T(x,0) = T_0 + h(x) \\), where \\( h(x) \\) is a heat source distribution function.

If at time \\( t_1 \\) an additional heat source \\( k(x) \\) is introduced, will the final temperature distribution \\( T(x,T) \\) for \\( T > t_1 \\) reflect only the influence of the original heat source \\( h(x) \\) and not \\( k(x) \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of an additional heat source \\( k(x) \\) at time \\( t_1 \\) adds another layer of complexity to the heat equation. Both \\( h(x) \\) and \\( k(x) \\) will influence the final temperature distribution \\( T(x,T) \\). The system's final state reflects the cumulative effect of both heat sources.
